headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Dr. Mandy Cohen is Interviewed about Covid and the CDC; Sanders Leads Colorado into Limelight; Fox's Grip on GOP Party Today. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Way through the college football world. They have a big test against Oregon this weekend. I think SC next weekend. Can Coach Prime pull off the upset?(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DEION SANDERS, COACH, UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO
utterances.sentences: Who ready?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Who ready?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Who ready?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Well, give me my darn theme music then, deejay.(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) GOV. RON DESANTIS (R-FL) AND 2024 PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: How good has CDC done, with all due respect, over the last few years? How many people trust CDC at this point? I was in the trenches during Covid. They were citing flimsy studies saying that masks will stop Covid. One of the things that I said is, when I come in, we're going to have a reckoning about all these Covid policies. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: We've seen a lot of misinformation, disinformation and conspiracy theories on -- online especially about the vaccines. And now you have a governor who is pushing some of this, saying that Floridians are being used as guinea pigs and he's just not going to allow it. What is your response to his statement?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Well, first, I want folks to know that these vaccines have been thoroughly and independently reviewed, both by the FDA and CDC experts. I'm - but, you know, I'm not just a CDC director. I'm also a mom and a wife and a daughter. I wouldn't recommend something for the American people I wouldn't recommend for my own family. My daughters, who are nine and 11, I plan to have them get vaccinated. I'm getting vaccinated. My husband. Of course, my parents, who are over 65, are at the highest risk, certainly want them to get protected.But really, unfortunately, Covid is still here us with. I know we all wish it would be gone. But it is here with us. But the good news is, we have tools that are safe and effective to protect ourselves.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It is here with us and it is still taking lives. I do want to talk to you about some of the issues that the CDC is facing because trust is really important for people to go forward and do these things, like get their booster shots. There were several issues. There was an initial faulty Covid test. There was lengthy school shutdowns that a lot of people railed against. Confusing or inaccurate guidelines on, you know, whether or not a mask is necessary, and then that changed to, yes, wear a mask, but then it was like what kind of mask should you wear, and all of those guidelines changed.What do you think the biggest mistake of the CDC was and how do you plan to fix it?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Well, look, we went through an historic event, right? This was a crisis that we hadn't been through before. Certainly a lot of lessons learned. I was leading the state of North Carolina, along with Governor Roy Cooper there, through the pandemic. We were certainly learning a lot and things evolved over time.What I want to do, as CDC director, is make sure that we are building trust, that we are being transparent, we're communicating clearly, make sure that we're doing good work for the American people, that they have common sense solutions to protect themselves. And that's what I'm focused on.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I want to ask you about the recent uptick, because we have seen the numbers go up over the last month or so. With that recent uptick there are several school districts that are now requiring masks once again. Is that a good policy? Is that something that should be happening that we go back to masking at point?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: You know, we're in a different place than we were before. We're outside of the emergency, but Covid is still with us. And we know that we have tools to protect us. We've been talking about vaccines being one. And I hope everyone gets an updated vaccine. But we have others. Testing, treatment and other common sense solutions. And, yes, masking is one of those solutions that folks could choose to use to protect themselves from this virus.It's important to know your own risk. Are you around folks who are older or who have underlying conditions? Then we need to use more layers of protection. The fact is, we have tools. We need to use them. And we're going to keep talking about the ways folks can protect themselves.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Do you think that this is a good recommendation, that schools should be masking now? As I said, there are several schools, I think Maryland one of them, where they're saying, OK, now you have to mask again.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Well, look, we want folks to be reacting to what they're seeing on the ground in their community and making sure that they're protecting themselves. We want folk to know that there are tools that they can use. But there are - are more things than masks. Remember, ventilation. Don't forget your vaccine. Wash your hands. Stay home when you're sick. These are layers of tools that we have right now. And we want to just empower folks to use those tools and - and support them in any way we can.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I do want to ask you about the vaccines and how well -- I mean how well do they work, and do they actually help reduce transmissions of the virus at all, this latest vaccine?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I can't help but tell you this story. I was in several hospitals at the height of this pandemic. And one of the things I heard from someone in the hospital, from one of the nurses, they said, someone came in here, they had Covid, it was really, really bad, they couldn't breathe, and the person's wife says, don't you dare give them that vaccine. It is dangerous. It is deadly. This is one of those big issues, this anti-vaccine sentiment.Do you have a specific plan to try and combat it, and how worried are you about a rise in this anti-vaccine sentiment?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Well, it's really important that we are communicating with folks and having longer conversations to make sure that we're addressing people's questions, that they understand the data, that we - we see -- it's why I'm sharing personally what I would recommend for my own family in terms of vaccination.I know folks want to be healthy, that they want their families to be safe. So, we're just going to keep communicating about the good information that we know, the scientific information that we're seeing. We want to communicate as transparently as we can and answer folks' questions. We encourage folks to, you know, visit cdc.gov and get their questions answered and engage with your doctor, with a nurse practitioner. Ask good questions and make sure you're using tools to protect yourself.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Dr. Mandy Cohen, congratulations. You are the new CDC director. Lots of work to be done. Thank you so much for answering our questions here on CNN THIS MORNING.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me, Sara.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, Deion Sanders, they call him prime. He's a thing.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: You may have noticed. He's completely revamped the Colorado Buffalos' football team. Already tripling their win total from last year. It's three weeks into the season, but can the Buffs and Dieon pull off their biggest win of the year this Saturday against Oregon?Stay with us. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: ANDY SCHOLES, CNN SPORTS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: He was expected to turn around Colorado at some point, but I don't really know many people at all who saw it happening this fast.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, Phil, Sara, I mean this has just been incredible what we've witnessed so far from Coach Prime. You know, Colorado has gone from winning one gave and being the worst team in all of the power five conferences last season, to undefeated, ranked 19th in the country, and really just the talk of college football this year.And in one off season, Deion Sanders, you know, he's orchestrated one of the biggest turnarounds the sport has ever seen. And he did it by just being the same prime time we've known for years. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: DEION SANDERS, COACH, UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO
utterances.sentences: Who ready?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Who ready?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Who ready?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I'm ready. SANDERSSCHOLES (voice over): The Colorado Buffalos have taken college football by storm this season thanks to one man, Coach Prime.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Here we come to get you! Let's go!

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: After three seasons coaching HBCU Jackson State, Deion Sanders instantly transforming Colorado into the most entertaining team in college football, and he did it by being unapologetically himself.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: I make a difference. I truly make a difference. I make folks nervous, man. I get folks moving in their seat. I get folks twiddling their thumbs. I get them thinking and second guessing themself.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: First thing Coach Prime did after getting the job, he told all the players he inherited to leave.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: I want y'all to get ready to go ahead and jump in that (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Coach prime overhauling the Buffalos' roster, bringing in 86 new players this season. And critics said his in your face brutally honest method would never work.

utterances.speaker: JASON WHITLOCK, OUTKICK
utterances.sentences: Everything Deion has been doing has been putting a target on his team's back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't like Deion in, you know, to give guys a bunch of pink slips.

utterances.speaker: TOM LUGINBILL, ESPN
utterances.sentences: For all the hoopla and all of the hype going into the offseason with Deion Sanders at Colorado, it does not mask the fact that they don't have any players on that roster.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: But Sanders continues to prove them wrong.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Do you believe now (ph)?

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: And Coach Prime has completely changed Colorado's culture, bringing unprecedented excitement.PEGGY COPPUM, 98-YEAR-OLD COLORADO SUPERFAN: I'm Peggy.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Peggy, how you doing?

utterances.speaker: COPPUM
utterances.sentences: Are you prime?

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: That's what they call me.

utterances.speaker: COPPUM
utterances.sentences: Do I call you that or Deion?

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: It doesn't matter. You call me anything you want.

utterances.speaker: COPPUM
utterances.sentences: Oh, well, how about good looking?

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Even 98-year-old Colorado super fan Peggy Coppum, who has rarely missed a game since 1940, can't believe what Coach Prime has brought to Boulder.

utterances.speaker: COPPUM
utterances.sentences: It's absolutely unbelievable. All this attention that one man has brought to this town, this program.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: For the first time ever, Colorado has completely sold out of tickets and the school says merchandise sales are up 819 percent from last season.Rapper Lil Wayne led the team out of the tunnel before last week's thrilling win over rival Colorado State. That was after The Rock was in attendance as Boulder hosted ESPN's "College Gameday." THE ROCK, ESPN'S "COLLEGE GAMEDAY": He's changing the face of college football and he's doing it his way. But he's also doing it in a way that - and this is - this is the hard part, that is galvanizing not only a town in Boulder, Colorado, but also galvanizing an entire country.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Wow. You're going to make me cry, man.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) recruits, did you hear him say -

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Two recruits that have helped Coach Prime's instant success in the Rockies are two of his sons. Shedeur is the team's star quarterback, Shilo, a defensive back, who wears dad's iconic number 21.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: I believe.

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I believe.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: I believe.

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I believe.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: I believe.

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: I believe.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Fans have known Deion Sanders for decades as one of the best athletes ever. But is he now the best coach in college football?

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Let me see a mirror so I can look at it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You feel that?

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Well, you think I'm going to sit up here and tell you somebody else? You think that's the way I operate? That somebody else got that on me?(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Yes, Colorado 21-point underdogs tomorrow afternoon as they play at tenth ranked Oregon. The Ducks, they're scoring 58 points per game so far this season. But I tell you what, Phil and Sara, you know, if Coach Prime can somehow pull off that upset, I mean, it would be hard to argue that he is the best.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).Andy, what would be your theme music exactly? I'm going to ask you yours, so get ready.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: What would be your theme music, Andy Scholes?

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Oh, me? I don't know. It wouldn't be as cool as Deion's, though, I promise you that.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I mean -

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Andy, I throughout you had it set up Lil Wayne was going to come into the studio at the end. That was kind of what I had my hopes on for a Friday.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Yes, he was -- he was booked, actually, already, for this morning, so -

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Oh, next week. All right. Well, when they beat Oregon, then he'll come in. That's great.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Then he'll come. That's cool.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Andy's got us, man. Andy's got us.I appreciate it, buddy. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Great story.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, one of the world's most influential media moguls is calling it quits. Ninety-two-year-old Rupert Murdoch, who built and oversaw a powerful right-wing news empire, announced that he will step down as chairman of Fox and News Corps, passing the torch to his eldest son Locklan, who will become the sole chairman of both companies.But is Fox's grip on the Republican Party as powerful as it once was? Joining us now, CNN's senior data reporter Harry Enten. Harry, give me the number. HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER: All right, this morning's number is two because Donald Trump has skipped or will skip two Republican debates on either Fox News or Fox Business. He don't care about Fox News and Fox Business. Why is that? Well, take a look here. News source GOP voters turn to most. And 74 percent say not Fox News. Now, the plurality leader is Fox News at 26 percent, but the fact is, most Republicans are, in fact, not tuning to Fox News as its main news source. Other follow-ups, social media, 12 percent, broadcast networks at 11 percent. But I think that this is a key number to keep in mind going forward 74 percent of Republican likely voters say the news source they turn to most is not Fox News.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: But I guess the other question to flip that is, does Fox News need Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is what I would say is absolutely Fox News needs Donald Trump more than Donald Trump needs Fox News. Why is that? Fox News GOP voters love Trump. His favorable rating amongst them, 85 percent. Look at the primary vote share he's getting with them nationally. The vast majority, 60 percent, are going for him, which, of course, is very different from what we saw on the other slide, which was the vast majority of GOP voters are not, in fact, tuning into Fox News as their main news source.But I will note this. All right, we had a New Hampshire poll you spoke about earlier today.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Wow.Harry Enten, thank you so much for all of those numbers.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Thanks, buddy.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All right, this week's CNN Hero watched as her teenage son Nik lost his battle to cancer. The one bright spot, though, during his treatment was his Make A Wish trip to Hawaii. When Nik found out that kids can age out of Make A Wish, he was devastated. The night before he passed away, though, he asked his mom to make sure older kids can still get their wish.So, this mom has dedicated her life to granting once in a lifetime experiences to young adult cancer fighters ages 18 to 24. For her, it's all about bringing a little bit of joy. Meet Kelli Ritschel Boehle. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KELLI RITSCHEL BOEHLE, CNN HERO
utterances.sentences: Clamp is in place. Are we all ready?Guess what, Abby, come on out here, if you can.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: BOEHLE
utterances.sentences: Congratulations! Yay! Surprise!When I get to see somebody saying, ah, my wish was granted. You are going to go to Hawaii! Sometimes there's tears, sometimes there's joys, there's hoots and hollers. Did we surprise you?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You really did. Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: BOEHLE
utterances.sentences: But, for me, it's Nik smiling down and saying, thank you, mom. Thank you, mom.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: My health has been getting worse. So, this is just everything to me.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, to learn more about Kelli's work and watch as one young woman gets her wish to go to a Taylor Swift concert, go to cnnheroes.com.That's it for us. Happy Friday. Have a great weekend. "CNN NEWS CENTRAL" continues with all of the news right after this break.
